title: Rumsan at the 4th National Dialogue on Anticipatory Action (AA)
content:
Shristi Piya and Shristi Khayargoli represented Rumsan at the 4th National Dialogue on Anticipatory Action (AA) themed "From Commitment to Action: Embedding Anticipatory Action in Nepal's Disaster Management Systems." organized by National Disaster Risk Reduction and Management Authority (NDRRMA) in partnership with the Foreign, Commonwealth and Development Office.

The two-day event focused on exploring anticipatory action initiatives across multiple hazards, including floods, heatwaves, cold waves, landslides, and others. It featured insightful sessions on Heatwave Early Action Protocols (EAPs), government-led policy developments, and interventions undertaken by development organizations.

The dialogue also included panel discussions on key topics such as the operationalization of the National AA Framework, the rollout of the five-year roadmap, and financing and sustainability mechanisms for anticipatory action. In addition, thematic sessions addressed triggers and thresholds, financing models, sustainability, institutionalization of early actions, and supporting frameworks.

Overall, the dialogue provided valuable exposure to the initiatives and activities being advanced by the Government, NGOs, INGOs, and private sector actors in strengthening anticipatory action in Nepal.

title: Rumsan at Devconnect: Showcasing AidLink at Ethereum World Fair
content:
Rumsan represented its work at the Ethereum World Fair stage during Devconnect, contributing to a panel discussion on real-world Web3 applications alongside Arun M. and Jos√© Ignacio Trajtenberg.

The session highlighted AidLink, a collaborative initiative between Rumsan, UNICEF Innovation, Xcapit, and Kotani Pay, designed to enable secure and transparent humanitarian aid delivery in low-tech and low-connectivity environments.

AidLink demonstrates how blockchain infrastructure can be purpose-built for inclusion and resilience. The platform enables:

  • Beneficiary onboarding using only a mobile phone number
  • App-free wallet creation with no private key or seed phrase management
  • Multisignature-controlled fund disbursement
  • SMS-based transaction notifications
  • Mobile money cash-out through Kotani Pay
  • Real-time transparency and traceability for implementing organizations

By prioritizing usability, accessibility, and open-source collaboration, AidLink showcases how Web3 technologies can move beyond experimentation to deliver practical, community-level impact even in contexts with limited digital infrastructure.

Rumsan's participation at Devconnect reflects its continued commitment to building digital public infrastructure that is inclusive, scalable, and grounded in real humanitarian needs.

title: Rumsan Showcases Rahat at Global DPI Summit 2025
content:

The challenge‚Äîhosted by Japan International Cooperation Agency (JICA), Gates Foundation, Centre for Digital Public Infrastructure (CDPI), Co-Develop, and Boston Consulting Group (BCG)‚Äîhighlighted innovative digital solutions demonstrating how Digital Public Infrastructure (DPI) can drive scalable, inclusive outcomes for people and the planet.

The summit convened over 1,300 global leaders, policymakers, technologists, and practitioners, shaping the future of DPI worldwide. Discussions emphasized DPI's role as a horizontal, interoperable, and purpose-agnostic foundation that enables inclusion, access, and equity across sectors.

At Rumsan, we are committed to advancing this vision by building open, system-level Digital Public Goods. Rahat leverages blockchain and mobile technology to strengthen national DPI and transform how anticipatory action and humanitarian assistance reach vulnerable communities.

Building on this momentum, Rahat has also been showcased for its DPI-based approach at COP30 in Brazil, reinforcing how open and interoperable digital systems can drive resilience where it matters most.

content:

Insights from Shristi Piya and Omnath Dhakal, our community partner from Punarbas Municipality, brought the discussion to life with real-world experiences from the field.

The findings highlight not only successes but also the critical lessons around co-design, community co-creation, trust-building, and preparedness, helping us refine and strengthen future implementations.

For us, partnerships with academic and research institutions are essential. They bring rigorous analysis, independent perspectives, and deep inquiry that help strengthen our solutions and scale impact more effectively.

title: Rahat X Danish Red Cross : Revolutionizing Flood Preparedness with Anticipatory Action
content:
Rahat collaborated with the Danish Red Cross and Nepal Red Cross Society to test its platform for anticipatory action during the 2024 monsoon season, supporting over 4500+ households. The initiative made early actions faster, improved decision-making, ensured transparency, and protected data.

This monsoon season, Rahat, in collaboration with the Nepal Red Cross Society and Rumsan, successfully piloted anticipatory action using the Rahat application. This initiative brought together technology and humanitarian response to proactively address flood risks in vulnerable areas before disaster struck.

With Rahat‚Äôs tech-driven approach, we were able to trigger early actions based on real-time data and forecasts. Relief efforts such as cash transfers and early warnings were deployed before the flooding began, significantly reducing response time and improving community readiness.

The platform enabled clear and timely decision-making through dynamic dashboards, allowing all stakeholders to stay informed and aligned. Communities received consistent early-warning messages, while our strong data protection protocols ensured personal information remained secure throughout the process.

Looking ahead, we‚Äôre working on an offline-ready mobile version of the Rahat app, improving overall user experience, and developing interoperable data systems to strengthen coordination with partners across the board.

This successful pilot is a major step forward in using technology to shift from reactive to proactive disaster response, protecting lives before crises escalate.

title: Rahat : Re- certified as Digital Public Goods Alliance
content:
We are pleased to announce that Rahat has been re-certified as a Digital Public Good by the Digital Public Goods Alliance. This recognition reinforces our commitment to building open, inclusive, and impactful technology that addresses the needs of underserved and vulnerable communities.

Rahat is an open-source platform that leverages blockchain technology to deliver transparent and efficient aid distribution. From enabling real-time cash transfers during emergencies to supporting financial inclusion and micro-insurance initiatives, Rahat ensures that support reaches those who need it most with trust, traceability, and speed.

Being re-certified as a Digital Public Good signifies that Rahat meets rigorous standards for privacy, accessibility, and sustainability. It aligns us with a global movement focused on building digital tools that serve the public good and advance the Sustainable Development Goals.

This milestone allows us to expand our impact by facilitating greater collaboration, strengthening our technical foundations, and reaching new regions where digital financial tools can build resilience in the face of crises and uncertainty.

We are grateful to the Digital Public Goods Alliance for this recognition and to our partners and supporters who continue to believe in our mission. As we look ahead, we remain focused on scaling Rahat responsibly and delivering technology that creates meaningful change for people and communities.

title: Shaping the Future of Humanitarian Aid: Rumsan at AidEx on Digital Payments and Identity
content:
On Day 2 of AidEx ‚Äì The Global Humanitarian Aid Community, Rumsan had the opportunity to join an important conversation on the future of digital payments in humanitarian contexts. The panel brought together leading voices from organizations, including Switzerland for UNHCR, Stellar Development Foundation, and Coala Pay, highlighting diverse perspectives and innovations.

Two key themes emerged from the discussion. First, the role of digital identity as a fundamental component of transparency. Establishing secure, verifiable identities is essential for building systems that not only protect individuals but also improve efficiency and accountability in aid distribution.

Second, the importance of end-recipient traceability. Ensuring that funds reach the people who need them most remains a priority, and leveraging technology to create clear, auditable pathways is crucial for donor confidence and effective delivery.

These conversations reflect a broader movement toward more inclusive, transparent, and responsive humanitarian systems. Rumsan is proud to contribute to this dialogue and to help shape solutions that prioritize dignity, equity, and impact.
